Criminal / Police

Pulled Over by Police

What to know when you're stopped by a traffic officer

Your Rights

5 rights in this scenario

You don't have to answer questions beyond providing your driver's license, vehicle registration, and proof of insurance. In stop-and-identify states, you must provide your name and ID, but you still don't have to answer other questions. Anything you say can be used against you in court.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: 5th Amendment, Miranda Rights

Police cannot search your car without your consent, a warrant, or probable cause (like seeing drugs in plain view). You can clearly say 'I do not consent to a search' even if the officer insists. A dash cam recording of your refusal can protect you later.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: 4th Amendment - Unreasonable Searches

You have the right to film or record police officers in public spaces while they're performing their duties. This is protected speech. However, don't obstruct the officer, get in their way, or interfere with their investigation.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: 1st Amendment - Free Speech

Officers must tell you the reason for the stop. You can ask 'What am I being stopped for?' If the reason is unclear, note it and mention it to your attorney later. The stop must be based on reasonable suspicion of a traffic violation or crime.

Source: 4th Amendment - Terry Stop Doctrine

If you are arrested, you have the right to request a lawyer before answering any questions. Say clearly: 'I want to speak to an attorney.' Once you request a lawyer, police must stop questioning you. Do not answer questions after this request.

Source: 6th Amendment - Right to Counsel, Miranda Rights
